content: The first thing might be to view the message source and determine what the character is that is forcing the new line. My guess is it's either the new line character or a paragraph mark. Many text editors can convert those to spaces. I suggest trying a text editor, such as the free notepad++ or whatever other you prefer. For example, Notepad++ has a simple Edit>blank operations>EOL to space that does it quickly. You may still have to find paragraph breaks, but this might help. Anyway, I've used this process before, so I offer for your possible use. Good luck.

content: Hola, La carpeta o perfil de usuario del Thunderbird se encuentra en la carpeta de usuario del Windows, si copiaron esa carpeta completa (carpeta visibles y ocultas) entonces allí están los datos: Por ejemplo la ubicación en Windows es: C:\Users\<nombre del usuario>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\xxxxxxxx.default\ "xxxxxxxxx" es un nombre aleatorio formado por números y letras, Usted o el técnico debería buscar en el respaldo que hicieron de su computadora esa carpeta, una vez ubicada esa carpeta se puede esar el siguiente procedimiento para mover los datos aun nuevo Thunderbird: https://support.mozilla.org/es/kb/mover-los-datos-de-thunderbird-un-nuevo-equipo Saludos

content: My choices do not resemble your picture. Mine is like this. Would hate to have to set apps to light mode to help TB understand that foreground and background the same colors is no bueno.

Is the non-sending account trying to send on the other account's smtp? Select the problem account in the left pane of Account Settings, then look at Outgoing Server (SMTP) in the right pane. Click Edit SMTP server to view the User Name; it should be the same as for the problem account, not the User Name for the other account. If there's a mismatch, click the drop-down to select the correct smtp. If it's not defined, add it to the smtp list in Account Settings.

content:
TRanslated to English using Google translate as this is an English only forum

Thunderbird archiving

Good morning. Is it possible to set Thunderbird to automatically archive mail? Maybe it would be enough to add the option Archive after xx days to the filtering. Please let me know if there is any other way to automatically archive e-mail

Auto filtering only occurs on new incoming mail in the Inbox folder.

All other filters you create which occur on older mail is a manual run of selected filter on selected folder or account.

Another option would be to create a search results folders which displays emails older than x days. Then periodically, select that search folder, highlight all emails using Ctrl+A and click on 'Archive' button.

How to create a search results folder:

  • Find > Search Messages
  • Search for messages in : select account name and then account name again.
  • select 'Search 'subfolders'
  • select 'Match all of the following'
  • 'Age in days' and 'is greater than' and set number of days eg: 35
  • click on 'Search'

Do not worry - it will also detect those already in Archives. You can alter this later.

  • click on 'Save as Search Folder'
  • Give it a name eg: Older than X
  • Create as a subfolder of : select account name and then account name again.
  • Click on 'Choose' button

It will list all the folders that are being searched.

  • Uncheck all Folders that are related to 'Archives', so uncheck the 'Archives folder and any subfolders it contains.
  • Click on 'OK'
  • Clear and Close the original search window.

You will see a search folder appear in the Folder Pane.

  • Select the Search folder calle 'Older than X'

It will display emails older than 35 days.

  • Select first email in folder
  • Use 'Ctrl+A' to highlight all emails

They will display as X Conversation in lower Message Pane.

  • Click on 'Archive'

The Search folder should be left in the Folder Pane. If you ever need to add an exclusion if more folder or inclusion of folders:

  • Right click on Search folder called 'Older Than X' and select 'Properties'
  • The window will look familiar - use 'Choose' to adjust selected folders.
  • Click on 'Update'

The Search folder should keep up to date and period ically you can manually select all and Archive.

Whilst this method is not automatic, it will help to auto display all the emails you want to Archive.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: The FiltaQuilla add-on adds 'Archive' as an action for message filters, which can be set to run automatically on the Inbox, or manually run on any folder.

content:
re :My email company changed to "Microsoft 365".

What was it before the change ? Did you previously use an Imap mail account or a POP account and is the new "Microsoft 365" account set up as an imap account in Thunderbird?

The company should have migrated all emails from old server to new "Microsoft 365" server. If you have now use an IMAP account, is it possible some folders containing emails are missing - do you need to subscribe to see folders?

  • Right click on "Microsoft 365" account name in Folder Pane and select 'Subscribe'
  • Click on 'Refresh'
  • Select all the folders you need to see
  • Click on 'Subscribe'
  • click on 'OK'

re :all the old email show read and tags are removed.

Emails previously downloaded will have a read status if they have been opened and 'Tags' are set in Thunderbird, it's possible those tags may not exist on the new server. If this is an imap account then all emails are stored on the server and imap accounts can only display what is held on server.

re : In fact the only old email I have are the ones that are from Mircosoft 365 till they made changes. (I'm glad I have a backup).

It would be useful to know what is have got backed up.

  • Access the backed up profile, locate the mail account name folder.
  • Make sure you have the View set as show details, so we can see the columns - Name - Type - Modified Date and Size.
  • Please post some images which show the contents of the old backed up mail account folder.

It should display the contents of the mail account folder, so that means mbox files (they have no file extension and contain emails), index files with .msf extension, if you have subfolders then you may see folders with .sbd extension. Note, those .sbd folder may also contain mbox files. It would be useful to know the names of the mbox files which contain the emails that you need to get back into Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : I do have a gmail account and all are gone even the backup. Now I have no idea what to do.

Need a bit of background info to understand your setup. In Thunderbird, did you previously have a POP or IMAP gmail account? I assume you recreated the gmail account and is it now an imap account ?

Just wondering - Why did you remove the gmail account? What problem did you have with that account which required it's removal?

Access the gmail webmail account via a browser - do you see all the emails on the server? Do you see all the emails, but they only display in the 'All Mail' folder ?

re:all are gone even the backup.

Post images showing the backup of gmail account name folder - View set as show details, so we can see the columns - Name - Type - Modified Date and Size.

Please note - in the profile folders, it is not possible to simply copy and paste any file directly into an imap account because when you restart Thunderbird it will check with server and only display what is on server. So this means any backup must get copy pasted into 'Local Folders' mail account and then after starting Thunderbird it can be copied back into the imap account and put onto server. I can offer advise on how to do this, but first I need to know what you have got backed up.

content:
1. As you originally had a POP account it would have stored all your emails automatically on your computer in mbox files and it was not necessary to remove it. If you have left them alone, they should still be in the profile name folder. We'll get to that later.

At some point I'll have to advise you on how to create a backup.

It looks like you initially copied only a bunch of pop files and put them into a folder - Documents > eMail You did not actually copy the pop account folder name - just it's contents.

In the pop account there was a folder called 'ChickasawDust' but that folder does not have a .sbd extension which is odd considering it's in a pop account set of files. There is also no mbox file of same name which is odd.

Instead the 'ChickasawDust' folder has a load of files which looks like yet another pop account of unknown name. But it's a bit odd because it has some files normally only associated with an imap account or in your case an exchange account.

Then you also have Desktop > eMail and also same location 'ChickasawDust' It's basically the same mess. Various folders and files of various accounts all lumped into each other and no way of knowing what server any of them relate to.

But regardless the only files that have any emails are all those that are called 'Inbox' (no extension). Anything with a .msf extension is only an index file used by Thunderbird, it does not contain any emails.

re: I then copied the files back to the email folders. They were there but very soon they were removed. You are using owl for exchange, so you are hooked up to the exchange server, and you cannot put back pop account files because they do not exist on server - they would get deleted.

re The old folder inside Thunderbird are all gone and replace with Archive, Bulk Mail, Conversation History, Email_Templates, Send_Later. They are gone because they do not exist on server. The files you are seeing are the folders on the exchange server.


Do this to get 'Inbox' emails back into Thunderbird.

In Thunderbird

  • Menu icon > Help > More Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way is Profile Folders - click on 'Open Folder'

It opens in a new window showing contents of 'profile name' folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now.
  • Click on 'Mail' folder
  • Click on 'Local Folders' folder to see contents and leave this window on one side because you need to put copies into this location.
  • Access backup Desktop > eMail
  • Copy the 'Inbox' file that has a size of 12,541 KB
  • Go to the previously opened 'Local Folders' folder
  • Paste the copied Inbox into 'Local Folders' - if there is already an 'Inbox' then do not overwrite it.
  • Then rename the pasted in 'Inbox' file as 'OldInbox'


Start Thunderbird you should see a new folder called 'OldInbox' in the 'Local Folders' mail account.

Did this get back a load of emails?

content:
In future this is how to create a backup. To create a full copy of everything just in case a full install is required.

Exit Thunderbird before you perform any backup.

  • In bottom search type : %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  • select the '%Appdata% file folder.
  • Select 'Roaming' folder
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to another Drive or suitable location

Create a fodler called 'BackupTB' EG: Desktop > eMail > BackupTB So the 'BackupTB' folder now only contains the 'Thunderbird' folder

If you only want to do a backup of the mail accounts: Do same as above to access 'Roaming' folder

  • Select 'Thunderbird' folder
  • Select 'Profiles' folder
  • Select 'profile name' folder
  • Copy the 'Mail' folder and if you have emails stored in the 'ImapMail' folder - copy that as well.
  • Paste the copies into EG: Desktop > eMail > BackupTB

Note if you have previously put a backup of 'Thunderbird' folder into 'BackupTB' - do not paste the 'Mail' folder inside the 'Thunderbird' folder - leave the 'Thunderbird' folder intact and separate.


This keeps all the different mail account folders intact and separate and it also backup the name of the account they were stored in.

content: Open Thunderbird and go to "File" and then "New" and select "Existing Mail Account." Enter your name, email address, and password associated with your work email account. Click on "Continue." Thunderbird will attempt to automatically detect the settings for your email account. If no click on "Manual Config." Enter your email account's server settings, which can be obtained from your IT department or email provider. This information includes the incoming and outgoing mail servers, the port numbers, and the type of encryption to use. Once the server settings are entered, click on "Re-test." Thunderbird will verify the settings are correct and you should see a message saying the settings were verified. Click on "Done." Thunderbird will now download your email messages.

content:
You said " I downloaded TB on my home computer - and I was totally surprised that the organization email address showed up without me doing anything at all."

This tells me you had installed and used Thunderbird previously. It tells me when you installed Thunderbird, it did successfully locate your profile and loaded the mail account. But it is possible you did not see emails etc because something else was not correct eg: server settings passwords etc etc. But it may also be because Thunderbird was not set up as an allowed program. Who knows - there are many reasons.


If you are using a Windows OS then:

The Thunderbird program will get installed in one these locations:

  • C://Program Files/ Mozilla Thunderbird
  • C://Program Files (x86)/ Mozilla Thunderbird

The Profile folders that store all accounts, emails etc ect will get auto created here:

  • C://Users/User name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/<profile name> folder

Windows OS also keeps a cache record here:

  • C://Users/User name/Appdata/Local/Thunderbird/Profiles/<profile name> folder

So if you Exit Thunderbird Uninstall program Accessed 'Appdata' and delete the 'Thunderbird' folder from both the 'Roaming' and 'Local' folders

Finally Empty the computer recycle bin then you would not have any trace of Thunderbird.

When you then install Thunderbird program, it will auto create a new profile and when first run it will ask you to create a mail account.

Suggestion - at this point - don't create account - do tha in a minute - first exit Thunderbird and make sure the Thunderbird program is set up as an allowed program. You do not want the program being blocked.

Access Firewall (Note it may be controlled by your Anti-Virus product) Set Thunderbird as an allowed program.

Start Thunderbird It will ask to create a new mail account. Create the new mail account for existing email address - as previously advised using all the correct server settings.

Then you follow the instructions previously given to create a mail account for the existing email address.


You say "I have all the files copied to a USB from instructions I followed here," You would need to be more explicit about that information. It does not tell us what you have got on that USB. Post some jpeg Images showing what you have got saved as that would help.

you say error says "Your Thunderbird profile cannot be loaded. It may be missing or inaccessible"

That implies you did not set up a completely clean new installation which uses a new clean profile. It implies you have been doing something with the profile folders and Thunderbird does not know what you've done.

It is possible you have not copied the correct data or not put it in the correct location or not set up Thunderbird to locate it so now it's stuck. Or maybe that profile you have got saved is just too old or corrupt. There are many reasons bit without further knowledge on what you do have I'm just guessing. If you have an older profile with any emails you need to access which are not available via the server (they were deleted off server)then that is a completely different question which can be resolved after you have set up the mail account.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: seems like a common problem with the new update

When you login to your Gmail account via webmail, do you see all your messages and folders?

Check your account settings which folder is set as 'Local directory'. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > Account Settings Select 'Server Settings' for the Gmail account in the left pane. Find the 'Local Directory' Option in the right pane. Copy the entire path set there and paste it into your reply.

content: GoDaddy support is awful - the change is because Microsoft is disabling "basic authentication" (sending username/password with each request). You should be able to keep using POP/IMAP so long as you switch to using OAuth2 for authentication (without having to use Exchange). Here's an article walkthrough: https://uit.stanford.edu/service/office365/configure/thunderbird-oauth2

This greyer box says "Checking password ..." and there is a partial blue spinning circle next to it. It just kept spinning and spinning. I decided to grab a bite to eat and see if it returned. It didn't. The only option available to me at this point is to click "Cancel" in this grey box, which results in an unsuccessful configuration attempt per the link.

Any idea what is going on? What I need to change/fix? Next steps?

Thanks!

content:
don162 said
BTW, my firefox (which I gather is this pop up window with the URL), is 114.0.2 while the newest is only a slight difference at 114.0.3.

That pop up window is not your installation of Firefox. It's TB's inbuilt/embedded web browser, but it borrows heavily from the Firefox project. It's not tied to or dependent on your Firefox installation in any way. In fact, the pop up will still open if you don't have Firefox installed. Just a note to remember that your Firefox installation is completely separate from that pop up and to regard them as such, because I've seen people trying to fix TB problems by tinkering with Firefox, while they don't even use Firefox as their browser! The newest Firefox is 116.0.3 BTW.

don162 said
I am at a loss what to try next. My Firefox and TB are up to date. I have followed the instructions in the link but it doesn't work, as per the details above. Has anybody encountered the same thing? Suggestions on things to try? Thanks in advance. Don

I don't have a GoDaddy account, so I haven't encountered the exact same thing, but I have had my fair share of Microsoft (Office) 365 OAuth2 problems with personal Outlook accounts. This was mostly due to Microsoft 365 not supporting OAuth2 for personal Outlook accounts, but after coming back to this thread a few days ago, I tried again on TB v115 just to see if things had changed, and they have indeed. Implementing OAuth2 for MS 365 on TB has been a work in progress and my recent findings confirm that things are getting better. I was using an app password with Normal Password authentication all along, which was less ideal, but I'm happy to report that's not the case any more. I had to remove the Outlook accounts and add them afresh on Thunderbird, because simply changing them to OAuth2 in Account Settings didn't work. I also noticed the url for the OAuth2 pop up was different for the existing account versus adding the accounts afresh. I will do some more investigations into MS 365 Oauth2 in TB 102 vs 115, for future responses to similar threads, but for now, I highly recommend you upgrade to TB 115. You'll get it here https://www.thunderbird.net/en-GB/

content:

I also tried clearing the cookies, data and cache and retrying but that made no difference.

Just to quickly restate what is happening when I follow the instructions in the link provided above, I get that window that opens ("Enter credentials for <my email> on outlook.office365.com") and in the "Setup your existing email address" window it says "Checking password..." (right above "Available configurations") and at the VERY bottom of the window it states "Mail for <my email>@outlook.office365.com: sending login information ..."

After a lengthy wait with nothing happening, I click Cancel and get the following message in a yellow box (where the "Checking password ... " message was):

"Configuration could not be verified. If you username and password are correct, it is likely that the server administrator has disabled the selected configuration for your account. Try selecting another protocol."

I have clicked on the Manual Configuration button just to review the settings and confirm they are as per the linked document. They are:

Incoming Server: IMAP outlook.office365.com 993 SSL/TLS Oauth2

Outgoing Server:

smtp.office365.com 587 STARTTLS Oauth2

Is there something about the linked document / these settings that is no longer correct? Do I need to configure differently?

Also, I have several accounts under my TB app; this GoDaddy/exchange account being one of them. It is an email I use for a business (very small "b" but business nonetheless) and does have emails I wish to keep. Is the fact that this email account is one of the pre-existing accounts within TB somehow prevent this Set Up Another Account function from working? Last year GoDaddy forced an account change upon its users and in that situation I was able to create the new account for the same email account, drag my folders and inbox emails over to the new account and then delete the previous account.

Thanks in advance to any and all that can assist with this perplexing and most frustrating problem.

content:
Remove that account from Thunderbird, Quit then relaunch TB and try to add it again. Leave the password field blank because TB won't be using the password for Oauth2 authentication. The Oauth2 pop up should show up. If the MS 365 sign in page still loads partially, then something else could be interfering with TB's Internet access. Security programs (e.g antivirus software) are notorious for this. So, which security program do you have running?

Is IMAP access still enabled for this account? Knowing Microsoft, their default security policy disables (legacy protocols) IMAP/POP and SMTP in favour of their Exchange protocol. You have to manually re-enable those legacy protocols to access using a client that doesn't support Exchange (such as TB).

You can narrow this down to whether it affects TB only, by setting up that account for IMAP access on the Windows Mail app. If the Oauth2 process goes through without any problems, we can try something else in TB.

content:
Update:

I have IMAP working. As mentioned above,

"First attempt told me that cookies were being blocked and need to be allowed. I changed my cookie setting from Custom to Standard, refreshing all tabs. Still the same problem (I tried with and without providing the password in the initial configuration window). I also tried clearing the cookies, data and cache and retrying but that made no difference."

It finally dawned on me that this has nothing to do with Firefox cookies as it has nothing to do with Firefox (as somebody mentioned above). The "browser" setting is for Thunderbird's "browser"! For anybody in the future that may come across this thread, do the following:

Tools -> Settings -> Privacy & Security. On this page, under the Web Content section, check the "Accept cookies from sites" checkbox.

I was able to create a new IMAP account (as per the link somebody provided early in the thread) with the same name as the POP account. Now I am just migrating folders and emails over to the new account and will then remove the old account.

Thanks for the help everybody.
creator: dgillesp220

content: Actually, I believe it had stopped archiving, and had already selected the messages, and then followed the new instruction of deleting.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks, but in fact, the status bar at the bottom alternated between archiving and moving to the Trash every half second. So the two operations must have been executed simultaneously. I was able to move the messages from the Trash to the Archive later on, so I believe nothing was lost (except that I got a lot of duplicates in the Archive for some reason). Also in the Trash, I had about 1,300 new empty messages with a date of Jan 1, 1970. These were probably archived before the deletion operation could move them to the Trash.
